Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Light-Driven Conversion of CO2 and Methane to Syngas
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research project is that the proposed chemical reactor utilizes methane from natural gas, a native resource, and waste carbon dioxide from industrial processes to create syngas, a widely used industrial gas. Syngas is a crucial resource for production of hydrogen, ammonia, methanol, and synthetic fuels. Hydrogen can be used as a clean alternative fuel to gasoline, ammonia is used in the production of fertilizer for food, and methanol can be used to produce olefins that are used to produce plastics. This chemical reactor uses LED light as an energy source instead of heat from burning fuel to consume two potent greenhouse gases and create a commercially relevant product at a competitive price. Using LED light allows for the use of renewable electricity, whenever available, to power the chemical reaction, in effect electrifying the chemical manufacturing process and reducing its carbon emissions. Some commercial benefits of this reactor are: (a) it is low-cost: built out of cost-effective materials such as glass, (b) it can startup and shut down on demand, (c) it can be made into large plants or efficiently scaled-down to build small-scale distributed reactor to produce syngas at the point-of-application.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to build and demonstrate a bench-scale photoreactor for dry methane reforming (DMR) reaction that uses LED light as its primary energy source. To date, DMR has not achieved commercialization due to very high temperature requirements and lack of commercially relevant stable catalyst. The presented photocatalyst overcomes the previous challenges with DMR. At lab-scale, it has has shown unprecedented high reaction rate, selectivity, and stability after long duration testing. This 6-month project will focus on three foundational aspects critical to this technology development: (a) develop a multi-physics thermal model of the bench-scale reactor in COMSOL to understand the energetic effects of the incident light and the endothermicity of the reaction on the catalyst bed, (b) build a bench-scale reactor and perform photocatalysis experiments to measure and optimize reaction rates and energy efficiency, (c) build a techno-economic model that can be used to determine the feasibility of this reactor for commercialization. Upon successful completion of the project, the reactor will be ready for a larger scale pilot implementation at a testing facility.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This SBIR Phase I project developed a photochemical reactor that utilizes methane from natural gas, a native resource, and waste carbon dioxide from industrial processes to create syngas, a widely used industrial gas. Syngas is a crucial resource for production of hydrogen, ammonia, methanol, and synthetic fuels. This photochemical reactor uses LED light as an energy source instead of heat from burning fuel to consume two potent greenhouse gases and create a commercially relevant product. Using LED light allows for the use of renewable electricity, whenever available, to power the chemical reaction, in effect electrifying the chemical manufacturing process and reducing its carbon emissions. Some commercial benefits of this reactor are: (a) it is low-cost: built out of cost-effective materials such as glass, (b) it can startup and shut down on demand, (c) it can be made into large plants or efficiently scaled-down to build small-scale distributed reactor to produce syngas at the point-of-application.

 

In this SBIR Phase I project, we had proposed to build and demonstrate a bench-scale photoreactor for dry methane reforming (DMR) reaction that uses LED light as its primary energy source. We successfully achieved this goal. Specifically, in this 6-month project, we focused on three foundational objectives:

(1) Build a multi-physics thermal model of the bench-scale reactor in COMSOL computer software to understand the energetic effects of the incident light and the endothermicity of the reaction on the catalyst bed.

(2) Build a bench-scale reactor and perform photocatalysis experiments to demonstrate substantial CO2 consumption.

(3) Build a techno-economic model that can be used to determine the feasibility of this reactor for commercialization.

 

In COMSOL, we built a Multiphysics model for our DMR photoreactor with the following primary conditions / assumptions:

  • Energy to the chemical reaction is provided by the LED light incident on the catalyst surface.
  • The endothermic nature of the reaction uses up energy.
  • The packed bed catalyst has certain porosity.
  • The material properties of all gases (feedstock) and solids (components of the catalyst) determine the transport of mass and energy within the reactor.

 

This computer model enabled the research team to estimate the temperature distribution at all locations of the catalyst bed in the reactor (surface, ?x? mm depth, ?y? location along the length) at different intensities of incident light. It also provided estimates of quantity and quality of fluid flow within the reactor under reaction conditions. These outputs from the computer model helped the research team optimize the energy inputs for the reaction as well as make design changes to the reactor. This information was also frequently used to design as well as cross-reference the laboratory experiments.

 

During the project, the laboratory experiments focused on demonstration of a bench-scale photoreactor for DMR that consumes 100 micromoles of CO2 per gram of catalyst per second while making syngas as a product. At the conclusion of the 6-month project, we demonstrated the said photochemical reactor at bench-scale with no external heating and only LED light as input. This reactor consumes 94 micromoles of CO2 per gram of catalyst per second. This translates to the consumption of 425 g of CO2 per day with a single photochemical reactor cell. In the follow on project, we expect to be able to improve the single reactor cell performance to much higher than demonstrated in this proof-of-concept project. The scale up of this reactor entails a collection of these cells arranged in parallel, i.e. a multi-cell reactor. Once this multi-cell reactor is developed (in a subsequent project), a 10-cell system (size of a household microwave) would be able to consume more than 4 kg/day of CO2, even at current performance levels.

 

A third part of this SBIR Phase I project focused on building a techno-economic model to assess the commercial feasibility of this DMR photochemical reactor. The model was built using Microsoft Excel. It incorporates all capital costs (e.g. cost of reactor and system components) and costs for operational parameters (e.g. cost of feedstock and electricity) as well as laboratory data to predict the cost of the photo reactor system as well as the syngas produced. At the current stage, this model provides the project team with the technical goals for the performance of the scaled up reactor (next project) that need to be achieved for commercial feasibility.

 

In summary, the project team successfully delivered on the proof-of-concept for the DMR photochemical reactor during this Phase I project. The scientific results from this project as well as the techno-economic model developed for this technology builds a solid foundation for a subsequent Phase II project for demonstration of a multi-cell photochemical reactor that consumes several kilograms of CO2 with renewable electricity as energy input.
